This game is the first one of these niche games of realistic modern RTS strategies.
This one's streamlined. The army build is flexible and diverse.
It has a lot of realism to it.
Overall it feel like you're watching wartime camera footage.

If you're a fan of these games - Broken Arrow is the genre's flagship.

If you're not, here's a quick rundown:
- Realtime strategy in which you don't construct buildings or units, but call them to arrive from your deployment zone.
- You're in 1 out of 2 teams, Americans or Russians, fighting for controls over vital areas for as long as you can until one team wins. The battles are set in Northeastern Europe, present year.
- You deploy new units with points which you get over time and through bonuses based on your team's performance.
- You build your army loadout which determines the amount, specialist units and unique units/missions. For most units you can customize certain features, with plenty of juicy dilemmas.
- Unit types work as realistically as can be expected.
- Visibility is a major issue in the battles. It decides battles, means of scouting are important. It's all very well done.
- Artillery is extremely important and diverse. You have to micromanage it by looking for the enemy positions and moving it around as well as managing ammo.

It's catchy. Beautifully done. It's fun.
Get it if you love realistic modern warfare and 21st century warfare as a theme!

This is one of the most brilliant strategy games released. This game is not comparable to Civilization, but more to titles like WARNO and Wargame: Red Dragon. Broken Arrow mixes the strategic depth of games like WARNO with more simplified Civ-esque unit interaction controls. You don't have to level up to unlock new battlegroups or specializations, you get access to every unit in the game off the bat. 

While I feel the experience of the beta was better somewhat, the new diverse collection of units is definitely better in terms of replayability. There are so many different deck combos to try and use, with a wide range of roles you can undertake. The devs make mistakes, but they do love their product and are trying to fix it constantly. 

Overall, the thrilling degree of unit customization, battlegroup creation, and gameplay loop keep me coming back. The strategic depth and options of other titles without the extreme clunkiness and massive friction. The learning curve is actually a curve, rather than a steep cliff. From tanks, to SF squads, to planes, to MLRS systems. All your favorite US and RU units are here.

Lately, I've been playing this a lot more than its main competitor, WARNO. Partly because I feel 5v5 is more managable than 10v10, but mainly because of smoother controls and a smaller, more detailed number of units.

It's great. Probably the best large scale RTS of it's type, but it may not be for everyone.

The modern broadly realistic weapons systems are quite fun play with. It's quite fun that you can zoom around a large scale battlefield and it works well at various zoom levels.

The gameplay is quite good, there's quite a lot of tactical depth and options available to you. There is a lot of unit variety. The way the balance works, you can hardly ever snowball uncontrollably and make a giant death blob, you always need to play tactically. The micro here is surprisingly good, it's based on sensible tactics such as laser designating targets, hiding behind cover etc.

The learning curve is quite steep, there is a lot to know and the campaign is hard. It's also a slow paced game with 45 min matches. Being familiar with the modern equipment helps.

I have never encountered cheaters, but people leaving early is a small problem. If a teammate gives up 10 minutes into a 45 min match because they made a few mistakes, it makes it harder for the rest of the team. The large number of complex mechanics can also contribute to this. When encountering a new tactic, a lot of inexperienced players assume it must be cheating and some quit because of that.
Needs more lore-accurate camos. Other than that, a bit buggy and the story development is great, a bit on the fantastical side and has bits of comedic relief.

It's a much better take on and RTS game in which range means more than traditional RTS. Rather than a front line fight with flanking attacks and sneak attacks, you have front line fights mixed with deep fights, supply line fights, aerial fights, aerial bombing, reconnaissance and ambushes. 
Much more detailed than traditional RTS games. If you are really into base building, this isn't the game for that. This is all about the battles.

It's finally time for me to write a review, which I probably should have done a long time ago.

I had waited patiently for this game for 5 years, and had been a Patreon supporter for STB for multiple of those years, including prior to Slitherine supporting the game as a publisher. I played the earliest alphas that I recall being available to patrons, all the closed and open betas, all of it. I provided feedback and felt that I was not shouting into a void. I at one point spent a couple of hours in a voice chat with one of the devs (FLX, this will have meaning later) helping create ideas for voice lines, and I think I recognize at least one that made it to release as something I helped with. I was asked at multiple points, because I was previously in the military, questions about fairly simple, small things that showed me the depth at which the devs wanted to go to create perhaps not a realistic, but immersive experience. My hope was through the roof.

Thinking back, the warning signs started popping up before the game released. The institution of auto-smoke for vehicles was a red flag. By this point, I had already realized that the feedback I provided post-Slitherine involvement was ignored (not blaming Slitherine, just using it as a time reference), and I can only imagine that providing feedback was an illusion of being involved in something we were all passionate about. The campaign was literally an afterthought because in the games formative years the team intended for it to only be multiplayer PvP. They didn't even think about adding skirmish until some of the later betas and the massive amount of feedback they received on that particular point (and we of course saw that enemy skirmish AI wasn't present at release, and allied ones still aren't).

On release, I had fun in multiplayer because it was a new experience, I could access everything rather than just some (as in the betas), but I quickly learned how frustrating the game was to play. Vehicle survivability was absolutely insane, and infantry felt incredibly weak (spoiler alert: this is still true because the devs refuse to make changes that would actually fix the problem). Many of us went from Wargame Red Dragon, where these devs also came from, which had incredibly strong infantry, to a game where the polar opposite was true. I don't need to belabor how awful the balance is because you can find what I can only assume are thousands of reviews complaining about it. I've seen people make tangible, constructive suggestions, only to be ignored on countless occasions. I've a good, longtime friend who is a popular content creator (>100k subs) who also told me to give up on the game, because he also tried to provide feedback after sinking countless hours into the game and understanding it at a fundamental level and was told he was wrong.

The anticheat, or lack thereof, is of course a core problem.  Most of the actual 'anticheat' was STB/Slitherine relying on Discord mods to read and evaluate cheating reports that were initially set up in the discord then were routed to a specific email address. Even with EAC implemented now, the original anticheat is still in the game. This means that modding the game is nigh impossible, and at this point, that is the only thing that will bring me back to the game: allowing me to not play FLX's version of this game. He is primarily responsible for the squandering of this title's infinite potential.

Here's the kicker: the game's state is completely in line with FLX's vision. If the community didn't have a say (through terrible reviews, diminishing player count, the Discord being full of negativity, PARTICULARLY the patrons, etc), I am 100% confident he would double down and keep things as they are. He completely, and openly, rejects criticism, whether constructive or otherwise. From my understanding, he similarly rejects dissent from within even the dev team itself. I've watched members of the moderator team leave or at least become openly critical of the game, not because they're volunteers/unpaid, but because they also share the cynical view of the game, which exists largely because of FLX. He is, in every sense of the word, the end-all-be-all decisionmaker. Recently, he asked me a question after a rather cynical scathing of the state of the game in the Patreon channel, I spent over an hour compiling what I felt was a constructive, holistic answer (the subject was, in particular not just on the balance but the OPTICS of the balance; i.e. how it looked having the community be the reason that the demonstrable lack of balance only got worse with every single patch since release), and he rejected it outright as a personal attack on the team (read: him). That was the last straw for me. I experienced his good side, but my opinion of him has significantly tanked and probably will never recover. In the words of the same aforementioned friend, "he's [FLX] is not typing a response, he already had all the answers." It was shortly after this that I cancelled my Patreon subscription. Sure, that is largely symbolic, but to go from one of the longest-time supporters at the highest Patreon level before Slitherine was in the picture to joining the cynics after release was never, ever something I expected to do. 

The sad thing is this: I still believe in the potential of Broken Arrow. Somehow, some way, I believe it is possible to salvage. I don't believe they'll ever truly balance the game as long as FLX has any say in the decisionmaking, but I do believe in what I can only assume will be years, the ability to mod the game will make it worth playing again (maybe you shouldn't make a modding channel in the discord if modding the game got people permabans from the in-house anticheat). Modding being added is exactly the answer I gave to the most well-meaning, awesome member of the Slitherine team involved in the game (Sam) when he asked me what would bring me back. 

My review doesn't even touch on some other broader issues, like the network affecting missiles, nor some other, more drama-related issues surrounding the anticheat that the vast majority of the community isn't aware of.

I'm forced to put text here so I'll try to keep it simple, though I could write a novel on all the catastrophic failures of this game down to almost every element. The game is struggling with technical issues that its been working through for a long time. They're a small studio, I get it, so I won't give them too much flak for it.

But gameplay wise...it's horrific. It's designed to attract players new to the genre/subgenre, but it has almost no staying power because of the absolutely baffling decisions on part of the Creative Director. To keep it short: Combined arms doesn't exist like it would in a Eugen game (or even really bigger titles, like COH); it plays more like a traditional RTS where everything is a stat check. This, along with the absurd economy of the game where there is basically no penalty for losing all of your units, leads to Bloons TD style gameplay where people just pivot from one massed hoard of unit types to another, hoping to overwhelm the enemy since units are quite spongey and usually can't be hard countered by just a specialist unit or two. 

The Creative Director himself is quite adamant that this is intended gameplay, and has stubbornly roadblocked other devs' attempts at overhauling the game with a few exceptions (Airspam used to be REALLY bad in the betas, but we got a rework by release). Other development problems cropped from the couple years of relative dormancy the game experienced, meaning the Singleplayer is very haphazardly and quickly thrown together (Probably one of the worst campaigns of any game I've ever played) and a lot of things are noticably half baked, like the UI and general stability of the game.

All in all, it makes me sick to my stomach to talk so much trash about this game because I really do consider many of the people involved with its development old friends, and I was very excited to see them go out and make a game I really feel has potential to fill a gap left by more stagnant RTS concepts and Eugen itself. Unfortunately, it ended up being a "What not to do" cautionary tale for game development.

Broken Arrow is the kind of game that makes you question whether your computer is broken or if the developers just decided to run a social experiment. It promises an epic modern-war RTS with tactical depth and then delivers something that feels like commanding troops through a PowerPoint presentation held together by duct tape and regret.

The performance issues alone could qualify as a stress test for both hardware and human patience. Even the best gaming rigs struggle like they’re running a physics simulation of quicksand. Crashes come often enough that you start treating them as tactical timeouts. And since you can’t save mid-mission—yes, in 2025—any crash means you get to relive the same two-hour operation like some kind of military Groundhog Day.

Then there’s the multiplayer, which feels like someone tried to organize a war game over dial-up internet. Half your team might vanish mid-match, and the game doesn’t even penalize quitters. You’ll spend more time fighting your own connection than your enemies. Matchmaking feels random enough that you begin to suspect it was designed by a random number generator that’s just given up on life.

The user interface seems determined to hide vital information behind submenus that look like they were designed by someone who’s never played their own game. The tutorials are so unclear you might learn more from watching a pigeon peck at your keyboard. And while unit customization sounds cool, it’s buried beneath layers of confusion, jargon, and buttons that don’t always do what you think they do—kind of like a nuclear launch panel labeled in emojis.

The campaign has ambition, sure. But ambition without direction just becomes chaos, and Broken Arrow proves it with long, joyless missions that feel less like strategic battles and more like endurance marathons for the clinically stubborn. The lack of saving is such a baffling omission it borders on performance art.

At sixty bucks, you’re paying for what feels like early access with delusions of grandeur. The game isn’t so much broken as it is perpetually under construction. Every time it shows a glimmer of promise—like a well-designed unit or a satisfying explosion—it quickly reminds you that fun is a bug, not a feature.

In short, Broken Arrow is a brilliant concept trapped in a catastrophic execution. It’s like someone handed you the blueprints for a stealth jet and you ended up with a lawnmower that explodes when you press “Go.” Maybe, someday, after enough patches, it’ll become what it wants to be. For now, it’s just a cautionary tale in real-time suffering.
